ygData.subject: Re: [neat] IEX - major update for a major oops!
ygData.msgSnippet: John, Congrats on finding the bug. If it makes you feel any better, over the last 6 months of last year I lost around 20 runs of 1,000 generations each due to

Subject: Re: [neat] IEX - major update for a major oops!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=82117382
X-Yahoo-Profile: jim_oflaherty_jr

John,

Congrats on finding the bug.

If it makes you feel any better, over the last 6 months of last year I lost around 20 runs of
1,000 generations each due to a small error I had in one of my methods responsible for generating
a descendant from a parent.  It took me a long time to hunt the bug down, because the effect was
inter-generational.  I just noticed that my ANNs would start off capable of beating a random
opponent and then rapidly descend to lose ALL games, including those versus random.  OMG, that was
confusing.

My problem ended up being I had done a *shallow* copy of my weight values array so the parent
player and child player were referring to the same array.  So, when the child's weight array was
mutated, the parent's changed as well (and of course should not have) due to the shallow copy. 
This subtle little bug wasted an enormous amount of time.

Well, I say wasted.  I went through all of my code from top to bottom so many times and ended up
finding a number of small bugs, errors and time wasters.  Additionally, I built a bunch of test
cases and a great report output mechanism so I could try and find the problem.  So, it was
marginally wasteful.  I just would have preferred to have done all that other work AFTER I had
gotten some results.

I did eventually find the bug after spending both weeks of my Christmas/New Years vacation hunting
for it (10+ hours a day).  And when I did, I realized the many gigabytes of data I had accumulated
was completely useless.  So I dumped, restarted and my ANNs finally learned.  YAY!

I think it is just part of the learning process - slow but sure progress in moving towards the
goal!  :^)  And the lesson I learned is how much JUnit ROCKS in allowing one to automatedly
validate an enormous number of conditions after a small change!  :^)

Good luck on your next round.


Jim


--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> I can't believe I forgot that critical step...
> 
> And I told myself... "Don't forget to update the variable inputs inside the 
> evaluation loop..."
> 
> But when I went in to add some code to weight the errors more heavily closer 
> to the center and less towards the outside, I was quite amazed to find that 
> the code for doing that wasn't there...I can't believe I did that!!!
> 
> So, the last 500+ generations are a total loss.  All it was learning to do 
> is take the average of all the inputs.  Which it was definitely learning to 
> do!  That's why it leveled out at 50%!  :)
> 
> Oh, yeah, turns out there was a major problem with my fitness sharing 
> calculations, too.  That's fixed.
> 
> Anyway, so I'm back at square one.  But now I actually stand a chance of 
> accomplishing what I set out to accomplish.  *sigh*
> 
> As for Colin and Ian, the auto-client-update code was still broken.  I fixed 
> (and tested) it now, but it's too late for your copy.  Please update the 
> client like so:
> 
> $ rm get_latest.sh
> $ wget http://www.hanlonsrazor.com:81/neat/iex/iex_client/get_latest.sh
> $ chmod 755 ./get_latest.sh
> $ ./get_latest.sh
> $ ./iex_client.sh
> 
> Thanks!  And thanks again for your donations of CPU time!
> 
> -- John
> 
> 
>
